msDesc.head: Composite manuscript with mainly epistolographic contents, in two volumes (together with Gr. 28B)

watermark.term: Coat of arms of Amsterdam; IB

bibl.title: Watermarks, mainly of the 17th and 18th centuries
Heawood

watermark.note: Possibly the countermark to the aforementioned Coat of Arms watermark.

supportDesc.foliation: Foliation partly in ink, partly in pencil: 1–225.

bindingDesc.p:
Inboard binding covered in stained brown calfskin. Sewn on five supports. Stuck-on endbands in brown and reddish-brown. Blue edges. Binding title on spine: CODEX MS. GRAECUS. Gold-tooled decorations on spine compartments, bands, and board edges. The same kind of tooling is found on books bound by Johan Nilsson Norman , who was active as a bookbinder in and was employed as bookbinder to the King’s Library . Cf.
Arvid Hedberg
http://viaf.org/viaf/76302191
Stockholms bokbindare 1460–1880: anteckningar Stockholm
.

history.origin:
The volume was, together with its sister volume, Ups. Gr. 28B, written in the mid-fourteenth century , based on the watermarks and the handwriting (partly in Metochitesstil). As it is an extensive composite of several autonomous units, it is not unlikely that the production was stretched out over a longer period of time. The following units were, according to , probably the earliest (1340s): units 1 and 5 in Ups. Gr. 28A together with units 9 and 12 in Ups. Gr. 28B; cf.
Gustav H. Karlsson
http://viaf.org/viaf/15379619
Codex Upsaliensis Graecus 28: Geschichte und Beschreibung der Handschrift nebst einer Nachlese von Texten Uppsala
. Dieter Harlfinger has suggested that, on the basis of the contents as well as the handwriting, the main scribe is likely to have been a pupil of Thomas Magister and Nicephorus Gregoras
; he first proposed that Scribe A might be Demetrius Cydones , in which case we would have a geographical connection to Constantinople . In an addendum, though, this assumption was corrected into an identification of Scribe A as Philotheos Metropolitan of Selymbria (
Gustav H. Karlsson
http://viaf.org/viaf/15379619
Codex Upsaliensis Graecus 28: Geschichte und Beschreibung der Handschrift nebst einer Nachlese von Texten Uppsala
). This still supports a close connection to the intellectual milieu around Nicephorus Gregoras
, to whom Philotheos Metropolitan of Selymbria supposedly was a pupil but later turned against (cf. the anathema preserved in autograph in the Register of the Patriarchate, Vindob. Cod. Hist gr. 47).
history.provenance:
The manuscript was acquired in Istanbul by Claes Rålamb , who was the Royal Swedish ambassador there in . Before that acquisition, the codex/codices (28A and 28B) had probably been in for some time, judging from marginalia and Latin titles added in the fifteenth century. In the late sixteenth century it was part of Mattias I Corvinus King of Hungary ’s library in Poland, according to the very accurate description of its contents given in a letter from (
Gustav H. Karlsson
http://viaf.org/viaf/15379619
Codex Upsaliensis Graecus 28: Geschichte und Beschreibung der Handschrift nebst einer Nachlese von Texten Uppsala
). How and when it returned to Istanbul in between is not known.
history.acquisition: Claes Rålamb’s library came into the hands of Charles XI King of Sweden as part of the payment of a debt. The library, including codex Ups. Gr. 28A–B, was thereafter donated to Uppsala University Library in .

msItem.title: Epistula
msItem.note: This letter has a connection to the one recorded on ; in the latter, which is the reply to this one, the addressee is called Beltandros. It may be assumed that Beltandros – real name or pseudonym – is here corresponding with the main scribe of Gr. 28A–B, viz. Philotheos Metropolitan of Selymbria .

handDesc.handNote:
Scribe A, Philotheos Metropolitan of Selymbria , who is the main scribe and the organizer of the volume (
Erich Trapp
http://viaf.org/viaf/46775099
Prosopographisches Lexikon der Palaiologenzeit PLP Vienna
). Writes in a distinct digraphic way, with one more calligraphic variant, suggestive of the Metochitesstil, and one more narrow and cursive minuscule. The styles may be compared, e.g., on , where the pinax on the upper half differs from the letter recorded below. That the two variants are by the same scribe is evident from other parts of the volume, where the two styles constantly take turns and also sometimes appear to transform into each other. The scribal hand, in both its digraphic variants, seems to be indentical to the one represented in the Princeton Gospel book Princeton y1957-19; that manuscript includes a colophon providing the name of Philotheos Metropolitan of Selymbria and the year .

decoDesc.p: Rubrics, glosses, and a few larger initials in red ink. The headpiece on is rather plain; just lines and dots, and a couple of flourishes.

msItem.title: Epistulae
msItem.note: With marginalia and interlinear glosses. The collection encompasses 154 letters from the recensio Lacapeniana. Cf. scribal note on :Αὕται αἱ γραφεῖσαι ρνϛʹ ἐπιστολαὶ εἰσὶν ἀπὸ τῶν σξδʹ ἐπιστολῶν, ἃς ἐξελέξατο ὁ Λεκαπηνὸς κῦρ Γεώργιος καὶ εὑρέθησαν εἰς τὸ βιβλίον αὐτοῦ. The number 156 is a correction in different ink of a previously written 155, but two of the letters are actually included twice: Ep. W 36 / Foerster 38 (τῷ αὐτῷ i.e. Μοδέστῳ) as numbers ρλθʹ and ρνεʹ, Ep. W 875 / Foerster 956 (Πρισκίωνι) as numbers πβʹ and ρμεʹ.

In the lower left margin of the last verso and/or upper right margin of the first recto. Most signatures are trimmed off. Traces still visible on
βʹ
δʹ
εʹ

handDesc.handNote: Scribe A, Philotheos Metropolitan of Selymbria ; cf. the preceding unit.

Scribe B (except for the rubric on , which is by Philotheos Metropolitan of Selymbria ). This cursive minuscule script is not altogether different from the cursive variant of the main hand, but should, according to Dieter Harlfinger ’s palaeographical analysis, nevertheless be seen as another hand; cf.
Gustav H. Karlsson
http://viaf.org/viaf/15379619
Codex Upsaliensis Graecus 28: Geschichte und Beschreibung der Handschrift nebst einer Nachlese von Texten Uppsala
. Scribe B has contributed also in Q13–14 and Q18, and is responsible for a few folios in Gr. 28B.

decoDesc.p:
Titles, initials, marginalia and glosses in red ink. Most initials are plain; larger flourished initials on
. An elaborate headpiece on , where the red ink is used to create white vine scrolls and palmettes in the voids.

msItem.title: Epistulae
msItem.note:
With marginalia and interlinear glosses. 98 letters (and 9 duplicates) are included together with scholia. For further details see
Ingeborg Hermelin
http://viaf.org/viaf/62578543
Zu den Briefen des Bischofs Synesios Uppsala
.

collation.signatures:
In either upper or lower right margin of the first recto. The unit displays some irregularities, including a twofold use of a couple of signatures. This may be related to the scribal work being divided between Scribe A and B; cf.
Gustav H. Karlsson
http://viaf.org/viaf/15379619
Codex Upsaliensis Graecus 28: Geschichte und Beschreibung der Handschrift nebst einer Nachlese von Texten Uppsala
. Signatures are visible on
βʹ
γʹ
γʹ
γʹ
δʹ

handDesc.handNote: Scribe A, Philotheos Metropolitan of Selymbria ; cf. preceding units.
Scribe B, the collaborator of Philotheos Metropolitan of Selymbria ; cf. the preceding unit.

decoDesc.p: Rubrics, glosses, marginalia, and rather plain initials in red ink. A few examples of more ambitious initials in pale red ink; see, e.g., the Epsilon on . A simple geometric figure in the margin of .

msItem.title: De insomniis
msItem.rubric: Συνεσίου λόγος περὶ ἐνυπνίων καὶ ἑρμηνεία εἰς τοῦτον τοῦ Γρηγορᾶ κυροῦ Νικηφόρου
msItem.note:
With marginalia, interlinear glosses, and intermittent commentary by Nicephorus Gregoras
.

bibl.title: Nicephori Gregorae Explicatio in librum Synesii De insomniis: Scholia cum glossis

msItem.title: Epistula ad
msItem.incipit: Ἧκεν εἰς ἡμᾶς τὰ σὰ θεῖα καὶ κάλλιστα
msItem.explicit: Ἐρρωμένος καὶ εὐθυμῶν διαβιῳης ὦ θαυμάσιε
msItem.note:
The authorship of this text, and of the three letters that follow, is not explicit. But one may assume that they were composed by the main scribe, Philotheos Metropolitan of Selymbria , since in the Pinax he mentions them as mine (ours), ἡμέτεροι; cf.
Gustav H. Karlsson
http://viaf.org/viaf/15379619
Codex Upsaliensis Graecus 28: Geschichte und Beschreibung der Handschrift nebst einer Nachlese von Texten Uppsala
and
Niels Gaul
http://viaf.org/viaf/95380886
Thomas Magistros und die spätbyzantinische Sophistik: Studien zum Humanismus urbaner Eliten in der frühen Palaiologenzeit Wiesbaden
. The letter to Beltandros is the reply to the letter recorded on .

bibl.title: Codex Upsaliensis Graecus 28: Geschichte und Beschreibung der Handschrift nebst einer Nachlese von Texten

msItem.title: Epistula ad Johannem V Palaeologum Johannes V Palaeologus Emperor of Byzantium
msItem.incipit: Κράτιστε, θεόστεπτε, θεοπρόβλητε, θεοδόξαστε δέσποτά μου
msItem.explicit: ἐστ’ ὰν ὕδωρ τε ῥέῃ καὶ δένδρεα μακρὰ τεθήλῃ
msItem.note:
At the top of there is a lacuna mid-text of a few lines’ length due to a tear in the paper. Beneath the repair with modern paper another one and a half lines are now hidden, viz. the following words: καὶ ἁγίας βασιλείας σου τῆς ὡς ἀληθῶς ἁμιλλομένης καὶ ἐξισουμένης τῷ Σολομῶντι ὲκείνῳ τῷ φρονιμωτάτῳ βασιλεῖ. In addition to the tear on this single folio, it may be assumed that a larger portion of folios have gone amiss around here, perhaps deliberately so; cf.
Gustav H. Karlsson
http://viaf.org/viaf/15379619
Codex Upsaliensis Graecus 28: Geschichte und Beschreibung der Handschrift nebst einer Nachlese von Texten Uppsala
. The Pinax on mentions more texts than are now present in the manuscript (Ἡμέτεροι λόγοι δύο προσφωνητικοὶ καὶ ἐπιστολαὶ δέκα), and the quire analysis seems to confirm this.

bibl.title: Codex Upsaliensis Graecus 28: Geschichte und Beschreibung der Handschrift nebst einer Nachlese von Texten

decoDesc.p: Titles, initials, marginalia and glosses in red ink. Most initials are plain or with just a small flourish. On a simple headpiece made up from a couple of lines and four trefoils. Astrological and planetary symbols in the margins, passim. On a cosmological diagram showing Pythagoras’ eight-corded lyre.

msItem.title: Disputatio de Paschate seu Epistula ad Demetrium Cabasilam Demetrius Cabasilas
msItem.rubric: Περὶ τοῦ πάσχα Νικηφόρου τοῦ Γρηγορᾶ· τῷ Καβάσιλᾳ κυρῷ Δημητρίῳ περὶ τοῦ πάσχα ἀπόδειξις ὅπως ἐσφάλη πρὸ χρόνων καὶ ὅπως χρὴ ποιήσασθαι τὴν τούτου διόρθωσιν
msItem.incipit: Ἐπειδή μοι φίλος εἶ τῶν πάνυ καὶ καινῶν ἀκροαμάτων ἐραστης
msItem.explicit: καθάπερ δὴ καὶ τὸ πρὸς οὐρανὸν τοξεύειν
msItem.note:
The incipit and explicit agree with the text in Codex Vaticanus 1086 although the addressee does not; cf. note 14 and 37 to the PG Migne edition, below. On this matter, see further
Hans-Veit Beyer
http://viaf.org/viaf/71879267
Demetrios Kabasilas, Freund und späterer Gegner des Nikephoros Gregoras Jahrbuch der Österreichischen Byzantinistik
.

msItem.title: Epistulae
Ep. 51
msItem.quote: Εἰ μὲν γράφοντας ἡμᾶς τοῖς φίλοις ἐπαινεῖς, μιμεῖσθαι χρή· εἰ δ’ οὐκ ἐπαινεῖς, γράφειν χρὴ καὶ παραινεῖν ὡς ἄρ’ οὐ χρή.
msItem.note:
The addressee to this short letter is unclear: Leone gives two variants, to Josephus Philosophus, monachus, or to Theodulus monachus ( Thomas Magister ), while Karlsson et al. mention Isidorus Glabas as addressee (
Gustav H. Karlsson
http://viaf.org/viaf/15379619
Codex Upsaliensis Graecus 28: Geschichte und Beschreibung der Handschrift nebst einer Nachlese von Texten Uppsala
).

msItem.title: Epistula magni Logothetae
msItem.incipit: Νέμεις ὤς φασι τὰς βίβλους τοῖς φίλοις
msItem.note: Ihor Ševčenko indicates as the possible author two alternative Grand Logothetes: either Constantinus Acropolita or Theodorus Metochita , with a preference for the first.

bibl.title: Theodore Metochites, the Chora, and the Intellectual Trends of His Time
The Kariye Djami

msItem.title: Carmina
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ Φιλῆ εἰς τὸν εὐαγγελισμὸν τετράστιχον
msItem.note: Some forty short poems; most of them are edited; cf. Miller I 1; I 4; I 9; I 6; I 11; I 13; I 14; I 19; I 17; I 18; I 228; I 197; I 16; I 20; I 21; I 15; I 22; I 223; I 23; I 258; I 122; I 142; an unidentified poem Εἰς τὸν Πέτρον, inc.: Τὰς κλεὶς ὁ Χριστός σοι χαρίθεται Πέτρε; an unidentified poem Εἰς τὸν Παῦλον, inc.: Διψῶ μαθεῖν ὃν οὐρανὸν λέγεις τρίτον; II 232; I 282; I 281; I 150; I 254; an unidientified poem Εἰς κέλλαν μοναχοῦ, inc.: Θρήνει με κέλλα σχοῦσα νωθρὸν ἐργάτην; I 192; II 114; an unidentified poem, inc.: Ὡς λαβίδα βλέπω σε φρικτὴν παρθένον; I 24; II 43; II 206; I 167; I 70; I 243; I 227; I 42; I 18; I 19; I 217.

msItem.title: Carmina
Carmen I 223
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ σοφωτάτου Φιλῆ στίχοι ἰαμβικοὶ ὡς ἀπὸ προσώπου τῆς πρωτοστρατορίσσης τῆς Γλαβαίνης εἰς τὸν παρ’ αὐτῆς ἀνεγερθέντα ναὸν τῇ παμμακαρίστῳ Θεοτόκῳ ἐπὶ τῷ τάφῳ τοῦ πρωτοστράτορος

msItem.title: Collectio vocum Atticarum
msItem.rubric: Ὀνομάτων Ἀττικῶν συλλογὴ ἐκλεγεῖσα ἀπὸ τῆς τεχνολογίας τῶν εἰκόνων τοῦ Φιλοστράτου, ἣν ἐξέδοτο ὁ σοφώτατος κῦρ Μανουὴλ ὁ Μοσχόπουλος, καὶ ἀπὸ τῶν βιβλίων τῶν ποιητῶν· συνεθέτη δὲ ἐνταῦθα κατὰ στοιχεῖον

collation.signatures:
The fourth quire of this unit was, probably by mistake, counted as number three; likewise, at the end of the sixth quire, the traces seem to correspond to number five.

handDesc.handNote: Scribe A, Philotheos Metropolitan of Selymbria , who has contributed in all units of the volume (cf. codicological units 1–5).

decoDesc.p: Titles, initials, and marginal glosses in faded red, or pale brown ink, on , in bright red ink on . For examples of flourished initials, see the quadrangular Beta with unfilled crosses and trefoils on , a Delta furnished with a vine, dots, and tendrils on . Similar embellishments are used also for the bright red initials later in the unit; see, e.g., the Rho on , and Psi on 210v. A pointing hand on .
